title: Elementary – Cycle 3 – Progression of Learning - English Language Arts (2009)
subject: Languages

document.title: Elementary – Cycle 3 – Progression of Learning - English Language Arts (2009)

CAB68B275B68400284AA72C1B6440D78.description: Written and Media Texts: Use of persuasive images, words or phrases to promote a product and/or some aspect of consumerism (e.g. on product packaging, in magazine ads, on a Web site for a popular toy such as Barbie, in a popular logo), Strategic placement of images (photo or drawing) to attract the attention of reader/viewer (e.g. as in a poster, in a magazine ad), Music/sound to promote a product and/or appeal to the viewer to take action (e.g. in a TV commercial) (Viewing only)

33C0DB48C47B4918B6C806DEF7AEB0D4.description: Structures and Features The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge to construct meaning/message when reading, viewing, writing and producing texts.

63365AB4780C42DF913593447FB9BBC9.description: Writing and Media Production The student writes/produces persuasive texts that promote a product, event or service aimed at children, specifically: Promotional posters or flyers (e.g. for a special event at school or to advertise a favorite game), Packaging (e.g. for a new toy, cereal box, video game), Ads (e.g. for a children’s magazine, for a commercial), TV and/or movie reviews for peers or younger children

E04A15EDC8024618A24089ECBC962EB0.description: Reading and Listening (written and media texts) The student reads/views persuasive texts that encourage people to purchase something, partake in a special activity or adopt a particular viewpoint, specifically: Popular signs and symbols, such as logos of popular food chains, clothing Packaging for popular products aimed at children (e.g. cereal boxes, toys, clothing), Promotional posters or flyers iv. TV commercials aimed at children, Magazine and newspaper advertisements (i.e. in children’s magazines), TV and/or movie reviews aimed at children (e.g. a movie trailer for a popular film or a TV show), Public Service Ads and posters created for children, Opinion pieces, print or online, written for children on topics/issues of interest (e.g. Should sports celebrities be considered heroes?)

13AACA51849D45768DEA103B8EB5E193.description: Speaking : The student produces spoken persuasive texts, specifically: Texts that seek to persuade peers to change their habits and/or actions and/or behaviours (e.g. appeals concerning the impact of plastic bottles on the environment)

7803C810B76C4C868F1CE89D196204B1.description: Media Texts: Headline or title to indicate contents, Images/ visuals to contribute to description of events, details, or impressions (e.g. in a nonfiction article on plant-eating dinosaurs, a brochure describing the school community, a blog about puppy mills), Images/ visuals to classify and sequence details, recounts, events and information (e.g. in a photo essay, in a local news story, on a website)

D0B1DA3736414225B432CCEC2F75E919.description: Written texts: Title to indicate contents General statement about the topic in opening paragraph (e.g. Dogs are mammals), Logical sequencing of details, facts, opinions based on events and/or information, Subheadings and paragraphs to group and/or categorize information, Use of comparison and contrast, Visuals and/or graphic organizers to extend content of written text (e.g. pictures, labels, diagrams) Summary of events, observations, impressions to highlight what is most important, Specific features of different formats depending on topics and purposes (i.e. a science report has different features than a news article describing the school community)

766F963851C04FA5830D18D27DEB52C7.description: Structures and Features The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge when reading, writing and producing descriptive reports.

03763B20709E4B0EAFF8836726EEAD65.description: Writing and Media Production: Reports on personal experiences in family, classroom, or school (e.g. an anecdotal report). Reports on topics/subjects of personal interest (e.g. short nonfiction texts, magazine articles), Reports about their classroom or local community (e.g. in a class or school newspaper, on a class Web site or in a class blog)

97AD1ECA84F74A43BE29A84A433317AD.description: Reading, Viewing and Listening (spoken, written and media texts): Nonfiction that describes and reports details about a topic (e.g. simple science trade books written for children), Articles in children’s magazines that report (e.g. on a topic, event) Letters that describe or report (e.g. a character’s letter that describes an experience or event), Local and national newspaper articles that are appropriate and accessible to children,, Local and national radio and television news reports that are appropriate and accessible to children, Web pages, blogs and Internet sites appropriate and accessible to children (e.g., short video clips)

D58AAD39D49448D2A2664455C23FCB08.description: Speaking The student produces: a. spoken reports based on family, community or school experiences (e.g. field trips, favourite toys, special holidays), spoken reports that describe the way things are or were (e.g. an observed event such as a solar eclipse, the stages of an experiment and what was observed, a report on a topic or issue of personal interest, such as the extinction of dinosaurs)

B999F3837D0A48F6A2B5BC1DEE578ED6.description: Spoken, Written and Media texts: A title and a series of logical steps, in images and/or print, explaining how or why something occurs, Headings, captions or labels to focus readers’ attention on what is most important, Sequential/chronological organization of information to explain how and/or why something is done in the way it is, Images (photo or drawing) and text features that provide additional information or contribute to the organization of information. Navigational aids such as table of contents or alphabetical listing in longer texts, index, headings and page numbers, Bibliography (if needed)

B73D2BB3EBD94780BFC5ACD70A26AC1F.description: Structures and Features The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge when speaking, reading, writing and producing texts.

56A2CD13983B4A2F9B914FB98D1DAC3A.description: Reading, Listening, Writing and Media Production: Texts that explain a process/procedure (e.g. rules, recipes, directions), Illustrated and multimedia how-to books, Texts that explain how or why something happens using a narrative structure (e.g. picture books such as The Magic School Bus, magazine articles), Posters that explain, Web sites (Reading and Viewing only)

46A16E0F7B7444059B787B1F43B41FD9.description: Speaking: Directions and instructions (e.g. for a game), Explanation of a procedure or how something works, Explanation of reasons for a decision

3D4AA190F68540C0A9D122848179F302.description: Written and Media Texts: Events/information in sequence (e.g. timelines, graphs), Chronology or ordering of actions to undertake, (e.g. in notes or lists), Visuals such as graphic organizers used to articulate relationship among actions or ideas, (e.g. webbing), Hierarchy of ideas/ information, (e.g. in an rough outline, diagram), Visuals/images for organizing or planning a text (e.g. arrows in a concept map to indicate linked ideas)

72079BC99A8F4C45A775690DCB540F92.description: Structures and Features The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge to construct meaning/message when writing and producing texts.

CBCF468A49A6416A8A774BC67D8C24E3.description: Writing and Media Production: The student writes/produces different planning texts, specifically: Learning/thinking logs and lists that record thoughts, ideas and information Webbing and mapping texts, such as story mapping, to represent the relationship(s) between ideas or separate pieces of information, Graphic organizers, outlines, timelines, graphs and diagrams to organize ideas and information coherently

9308C186BF274BF6A1DD0AED288BA9E0.description: Speaking and Listening: Understands the use of talk to compose a first draft of thoughts, ideas, and information, Understands the use of talk to clarify the steps in a procedure or an organizational plan (e.g. brainstorming, pulling ideas together, asking pertinent questions)

B5CE516EBD1F46CB8879BBD3A31A09F0.description: Text Types, Structures and Features: Information-Based Text Types

30E792BAA73948BCB2741AFD7FEF6A95.description: Media texts All of the structures and features of written narrative (above) also apply to narratives in the media. In addition, the student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when viewing and producing media texts. Plot structure and features Use of images (photos or drawings) to extend the story and to provide story details, Use of music and/or sound to create suspense, mood, humor, conflict, etc. (Viewing only); Use of colour to suggest emotion, to create mood, etc. Use of different scenes or episodes to move the story forward (Viewing only); C haracterization Surface appearance of a character (e.g. clothing, physical attributes), Use of details to convey an imaginary character (e.g. wings, exaggerated or invented facial features), Use of explanation marks and speech bubbles to show thought and dialogue, e.g. in comic books or some animation films, Use of body language and gesture to convey character traits, including emotions (Viewing only), Use of music and/or sound to signal or stress some aspect of character, e.g. music to signal the reappearance of a character such as Tinkerbell or Captain Hook in Peter Pan (Viewing only), Use of camera angle (e.g. use of low angle to make someone look stronger or like a bully, high angle to make someone look weaker or vulnerable), Stereotypes of individuals and groups (e.g. perceptions about gender in comics and picture books) (Viewing only); Setting Repetition of symbols, or motifs, to create mood, suspense, sense of continuity (e.g. scenes of the ocean in a story that takes place in Cape Breton) (Viewing only), Use of light and dark (e.g. to create a sense of foreboding, to change time frame) (Viewing only), Clothing and other details that create a sense of time and location

66A5058EDA424A57A5381E4FE1EFE6B8.description: Spoken and Written Texts: Plot structures and features- Predictable story patterns, Sequence of events, Incidents (e.g. actions that take place in the story usually related to the main conflict); Foreshadowing, i.e. the use of hints or clues to suggest what will happen later in the story (Reading only), Flashback (Reading only), Episodes, e.g. typically the subject of a chapter (Reading only), Conflict, i.e. central problem around which a story is typically organized. Examples would include man against man, man against nature, issues involving what is right or wrong, etc., Resolution of conflict Theme, i.e. the central or underlying meaning or dominant idea(s) that structures a narrative. It should be noted, however, that theme is not a textual structure that every reader interprets in exactly the same way. Characterization- Main character in a story; Setting-  The physical landscap and social context in which the action of story occurs, i.e. its time and place and  Descriptive details that construct the world of the story (e.g. the forest in Max’s room allows the reader to move into the story); Other features of narrative- Literary conventions (e.g. "Once upon a time" in a fairy tale, moral in a fable), Humor, suspense, repetition and Dialogue, e.g. to reveal character, Point of view, i.e. narrative voice in first or third person, Attitude of author to the material, i.e. writer’s position (Reading only)

2E2B08772CB847448CD7063A1E7B36DA.description: Structures and Features: The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge to construct meaning when reading, listening to and producing spoken and written texts.

0EDE2C5B9AA248A894C72DA681A01FC2.description: Writing and Media Production: Stories based on ideas, experiences and events,. Illustrated narrative in comic strip using own drawings, images or photos , Illustrated picture books using drawings and/or images and/or photos, Photo stories (e.g. sequencing photos and/or images to create a scene from a story)

177EC57340F4467294DDE0842793D0BB.description: Reading and Listening (written and media texts): Children’s literature: Nursery rhymes, Illustrated wordless and picture books written for younger children, Illustrated wordless and picture books written for older children with more sophisticated concepts, language, issues, characterization, etc,. Poetry Classic and modern fairy tales, Early/beginning chapter books,; Young adult literature: Age appropriate popular, contemporary fiction (e.g. novels, poetry, graphic novels), Media texts Comic strips, Stories in children’s magazines, illustrated picture books, online talking books (i.e. that combine spoken word and print), Age appropriate films, video clips, animation, Nonfiction (written and media): Biographical picture books of increasing sophistication, Articles in children’s magazines or online Web page (e.g. about a sport star, civil rights activist), Memoir in a variety of text types

3EC26ED7CD7E4F1D982A7A43A7A074CD.description: Speaking: The student produces own stories, as well as dramatizations of others’ stories, through: a. Role-play involving character from own stories, from literature and from nonfiction and Storytelling

C7D9AC7276104A638E15D946CA53D83B.description: Text Types, Structures and Features: Narrative and Literary Text Types

7DB7AFE3D52843299BA182560138F48B.description: Writing and Media Production: Self-expressive language to relate ideas, feelings, experience Word choice to indicate a specific time frame (e.g. past tense to indicate a memory), Synthesis of ideas and feelings to focus on what is most important

924BA22429BB4E5E9E0CCA24EF5DED2B.description: Structures and Features: The student understands the purpose of the following structures and features and uses this knowledge when reading and writing/producing texts

575537CF9C534B619EE4BDBD0F68D985.description: Speaking: Texts that focus on reflecting and evaluating own learning, in reading/ writing/ production conferences, including sharing of Integrated Portfolio

027C9A87545C4F098EDA9F4B1C23D65B.description: Reading, Writing and Media Production" Salutation, body and closing in a friendly letter, Relevant details such as time, place and location in an invitation Suitable message, given the communication context, in thank-you notes and greeting cards , Images (photo or drawing) to respond to the reader’s expectations and/or needs (e.g. the illustration on a thank-you note or invitation), Self expressive language to relate ideas, feelings, experiences (e.g. in own poetry), Self-expressive language in poetry: line breaks or stanzas, images, figurative language to create vivid pictures.

8A6F5322D79C4DF39FC74090DEC73994.description: Reading, Listening, Writing & Media Production: Thank-you notes, Invitations, Greeting cards, Friendly letters Poetry of different kinds written by and for children (e.g. free verse, list poems, rap, shape poems, free verse)

59BE07D5AD2C4B08AC7533CE98A42249.description: Speaking: Formal and informal thank-yous, expressions of appreciation and support and Formal and informal introduction (e.g. of a guest speaker)

2EBD7ADE76A8445F91A15D353D42A960.description: Texts That Reinforce or Maintain Relationships With Others

46F89097D8FA465395CB32F24CDD84D7.description: Text Types, Structures and Features: Self-Expressive Text Types

F8E4A57577134B7DB501296561F1B6DA.description: Evaluates the effectiveness of the text given audience and purpose

91249C86EB2B4A5DB728A6E3BA3D9426.description: Considers feedback from peers and others

334653E25C9D4858834CDE4CBC0818D2.description: Reviews images, records narration, adds titles or text, adds transitions, depending on the production and its message/meaning

70EA1761FD44416B85B5D79B06E0D541.description: Uses appropriate technology resources for the specific production as needed (e.g. downloading digital images for a multimedia picture book, using a still or video camera, adding visual effects and/or animation to a comic strip)

5E082B6825FE4B1FB6A331B592E361CB.description: Uses storyboard and/or other planning resources to guide production of the text

3D01E745D590453580B8EC55D55C220A.description: Uses images and/or print and/or sound to produce a familiar media text

35950AF4195A4DB486802CDA58CCC70E.description: Uses prior knowledge of media text type from experiences with similar texts, immersion into text

2C2E9093D9F046549CD8F36E3DEA5BBB.description: Determines criteria for production of a familiar text type (e.g. features of an effective poster or PSA, target audience)

2B7C3821D4C7445493440645C0356E03.description: Identifies and gathers material, resources, expertise for the production

F3124024402D40189A4CA84D067B14EE.description: Drafts storyboard (i.e. a plan or representation of the project)

C641F67637984ED89BBDD42DBBC76368.description: Examines models of text type to be produced through immersion into the type (e.g. unique features of a text, target audience, how message/meaning is communicated)

B13D3742F6874C46A0BE5DF55FEB6BA7.description: Selects text type depending on purpose, audience and context

3BED9FBD90B54D2982923C6A75F84776.description: Understands the purpose for the production (e.g. to sell something, to influence the way people think, to give information, to entertain)

14DB97A490374C8C8640DED115A7FD43.description: Feedback: seeks and provides throughout all stages of the writing process

F0FEE85F340240A68FB253FEB92AB44D.description: Selects layout and highlights relevant structures and features to enhance the presentation

FD35862F6CBE4209B796FE72070E0665.description: Selects personally significant pieces of writing to publish

382F8E2F1E0249E29DF92EE13D61EA84.description: Rearranges sentences and paragraphs for clarity and effect

D12F1BDDC1AA4B858B0059E0B4C80B1F.description: Checks for spelling, punctuation and capitalization

75404300E12A4B43882BF37897E8E7E1.description: Editing, i.e. rearranging/re-ordering what has already been written and proofreading

DC758AA72BE14D39BE73EDB6F4242996.description: Adds descriptive words and sufficient details

AD06D3793DE34FDEB4AA3536A5BD6902.description: Revision, i.e. making changes to content of text and/or message and/or meaning

6A910FE878304941AECECB478AD99675.description: Connects needs and expectations of a specific audience to writing decisions (e.g. provides additional details or information, sequences events or information to enhance reader’s comprehension)

17371B3F9F1942AF8CA75144EE258E07.description: Adjusts writing decisions to purpose and audience (e.g. the register and syntax of a postcard, flyer and letter are different)

D8B30379C22B4B3384C52B5C4EB2EAA4.description: Uses a structure that fits the type of writing (e.g. letter format, narrative)

EB44E9AE22FE42BFA0A1E3EA7CCABBCE.description: Writes to a specific wider audience on self-selected and assigned topics, issues and concerns

DB3CD23EFFF64EAB94939538A65758CA.description: Writes to a specific familiar audience of family, friends and teacher

ABED1215731A4333A455BEA7C651CFBF.description: Drafting, i.e. initial version(s) of texts

C98565AB48844A239D763A1B528C4B24.description: Examines models of text type through immersion into the text (e.g. features of text, strategies author used to craft the text)

BE175770FF8D487DB96CEB7CAD0D4D8D.description: Selects topic and text type based on purpose and audience

1BA560C64B9A4DFE9F1D549EA536A424.description: Understands the purpose for the writing (e.g., to entertain, to inform, to communicate)

839815E141DC421A9981194E7E69D433.description: Understands that texts must be questioned, since they are constructed by people with specific purposes in mind: Determines the specific or target audience by selecting details from the text (e.g. a magazine ad all in pink is probably targeting girls), Identifies and locates information about who wrote the text (i.e. its writer/producer) and why (i.e. the purpose), Examines how the message attracts and holds the reader’s/viewer’s attention, Distinguishes fact from opinion, and real from imaginary, Considers who/what has been left out of the text and why this might be, Identifies some of the ways that the author/producer has tried to influence the reader/audience

D3A702E6D8AA40A69D35D213E81EB63E.description: Understands that all spoken, written and media texts are constructed by people to appeal to a specific or target audience

431592D388AE4FF8BB60F129DBDA0427.description: Uses other readers’ interpretations to clarify and extend own ideas (e.g. discusses information, ideas and new insights with peers)

E4AFD3F80382418D9F26B67E5FF9FE46.description: Uses evidence to distinguish between own thinking, values and beliefs and those presented in the text (e.g. figures out what values are important to a character)

2A836796EB6C4028A15E64EA129A93FE.description: Integrates new information with what is already known to construct meaning

1197F18F5CEC46A2B9C12869FBC0E381.description: Uses details and evidence in the text to infer meaning(s)

D987B6E367884848BD7FC9481653D9EC.description: Constructs a personal response to the text (i.e. constructs meaning)

C1935447E7FB4B56B4B6900D2EEBAA00.description: Uses the purpose for reading and clues in the text to determine important aspects of a text (e.g. nonfiction features that signal importance such as boldface print, italics)

B4FE7348E4EF40869379640B0C1C2B9C.description: Recognizes the most common rhetorical conventions of information-based texts to build meaning, namely: Description of ideas and concepts, Sequence/chronology ,Compare/contrast, Problem-solution, Cause- effect.

CA29EF495A1C42EDA1AD1545DED4A284.description: Relies on common structures and features of media texts to construct meaning

F2F09766A3574C10BA007162063AA717.description: Relies on common structures and features of literary, popular and information-based texts to construct meaning (e.g. narrative structure: beginning, middle, end; or a feature such as dialogue)

6B9D7DDA3A7E4005B43F3AE4094ECDB7.description: Uses a variety of reading strategies to make meaning of different text types

2FBA976AA1E24435805E319514B94393.description: Applies knowledge of cueing systems to construct meaning

0114FAC7D72F491788C60518DA345353.description: Makes explicit connections between own personal experiences and story experiences

10A5A202FF8249E6B94C01A86E3776A0.description: Builds needed background knowledge and experiences (e.g. of content, setting and/or author, in a variety of ways such as watching a documentary on a related topic, reading a picture book on a similar theme before reading a chapter book, using the Internet)

EBC73AC61B5347BCA349F34A3B95A1C6.description: Uses knowledge of the genre/text type to be viewed/read: immersion into models of the text type to determine important structures and features of the text type, and how these contribute to meaning in the text (e.g. understands the structure and features of familiar text types such as main character, sequence of events in narratives [stories]; visual features in information-based texts)

E1AFA01D0620409DB98BA623D18A82C6.description: Previews the text (e.g. attends to the cover, dedication, title page and author’s notes for clues that will add to understanding or enjoyment of the text)

4F020B8B4DC142528B31BD26EBE2DB13.description: Uses prior knowledge (e.g. what s/he already knows about the topic, author, genre/text type)

7F6EF4EBA0BC43CC843D20256DA232A3.description: Understands the purpose for reading, listening to and/or viewing (e.g. for enjoyment, to learn something, to escape to new places, for instructions)

83F0D684C82C4F8F81A8A446227B3B4D.description: Visuals that convey information and/or ideas, such as timelines, graphs, graphics in comic books

1D4AD06AD3B1486BACDD9A8D6CF39D9D.description: Sound—in television, movies, some commercials (e.g. scary music indicates suspense)

0D0E454980124B69BA7EF84133479559.description: Uses and interprets camera techniques, such as camera distance (e.g. long and medium shots, close-ups)

5175F8D0D592481899F2148D3C023ECE.description: Uses and interprets the visual element of perspective in illustrations or drawings (e.g. to connote a viewpoint, as in a faded, distant image that evokes a memory)

F35AC5E3AEB94104827E0DAD17489AF9.description: Uses and interprets the visual element of color (e.g. dark reds and blacks in a picture book to show anger or fear)

60A2B291164540E893E0105A3AA1D9D9.description: Spelling : Indicates words that are misspelled, Applies common spelling patterns/generalizations including: word families, regular plurals, prefixes, suffixes, irregular plurals, words ending in –y, doubling final consonant, Uses resources to correct own spelling (e.g. environmental print, word lists, dictionaries, peers, spell check).

360F5CEAC91A43468AB1945831E630B7.description: Punctuation: Applies end punctuation rules: period, question mark, exclamation point, Applies rules for commas: items in a series, greetings, Uses apostrophes to punctuate contractions and singular possessive, Uses quotation marks to punctuate dialogue.

E21AE8C3E28745F6A8BC4C155F2BD3B5.description: Capitalization: Applies capitalization rules: the first word in a sentence, proper nouns

E9DFF43660CA4E31B342C46C020D36D9.description: Uses literal and figurative language in a variety of ways (e.g. imitating, creating new words, rhyming)

3AFE7342EEC7407880B7305ECB1618D7.description: Selects words that convey the intended meaning and create a picture in the reader’s mind

E136A2D3498A44F18B870DC35C4EA8C4.description: Uses consistent verb tenses and correct pronoun references

C568182A6F234ED4B287590315747D7F.description: Uses vocabulary and/or terminology related to the type of writing

0451E142978C4DAFAA151E7A9BF97428.description: Uses linguistic structures and features to express thoughts, ideas and information for a specific purpose and audience: In simple sentences by using subject, verb, modifier In syntactic structures that carry meaning, (e.g. the structure of a question, an apology, a request). In compound sentences by using prepositions, conjunctions, interjections, In simple and compound sentences (i.e. varies types of sentences and uses transitional phrases).

B84D7DCCD4B7479CABB9BDF88E8A0AE1.description: Writes sentences in an order that supports a main idea or story

2C5CCA9251454B8A9C8D9606996E8259.description: Understanding the Conventions of Written Language

4FC14513BE3B4706809A0F748DE141C6.description: Conventions of Written and Media Language
